CATEGORIES
#
585 Gold Blade Swords
Discover the popular reverse sword grip fighting stance commonly seen in media. Explore what it means, its benefits, drawbacks, and its use in history.
925 Silver Blade Swords
The enigmatic reverse sword grip: Unraveling its symbolism, tactical advantages, potential limitations, and tracing its evolutionary path in battle.
A
There are currently no sword terminologies for letter ”A”
B
Backsword
A sword blade, which has a cutting edge only on one side. Most commonly found on curved blades, such as sabers, falchion, and cutlass.
Basket
An arrangement of steel bars, and panels that form a basket-like cage around the grip (and the wielder's hand). These are most commonly found on Scottish basket-hilted swords, and European rapiers.
Behmer Typology
Typology categorizing swords of Anglo-Saxon origin.
Blade
The section of the sword, which is not part of the hilt.
C
Chappe
A flap of leather attached to a sword's crossguard, which serves to protect the mouth of the scabbard and prevent water from entering. Also called a Rain Guard.
Cruciform
A generic term for any sword which when inverted point downward will form the shape of a crucifix. This was, to a degree, a religious symbol to the knights of the crusading era.
D
There are currently no sword terminologies for letter ”D”
E
Edge
The cutting portion of the sword's blade.
Cruciform
A generic term for any sword which when inverted point downward will form the shape of a crucifix. This was, to a degree, a religious symbol to the knights of the crusading era.

Products Classification

We carefully choose our suppliers, resulting in a diverse inventory of products. Our categories include Practice Swords , Casual Swords, Superior Swords, and Authentic Swords. Classification isn't solely price-based and may change dynamically due to various factors.

Most products have a 30-day return policy from the day you receive the package. Custom-made swords are eligible for replacement only.

Types of Materials

You're a Japanese sword smith around 1500 or so. In contrast to your European counterpart, you are not seen as an undistinguished dirty craftsman but as an accomplished expert and artist, sort of.

You were on level three of the social ladder (level 1 were the samurai, level 2 the peasants) but one above the merchants and bankers!

Type Steel Description
Maru Hagane (Hard Steel) not laminated; poorest method
Honsanmai Kawagane & Shigane (Medium / Soft Steel) most common lamination method
Maru Hagane (Hard Steel) not laminated; poorest method
